reviewText: First of all, I watched this movie with my family with no idea what to expect, except that we were told 'we had to watch it'.Without realizing this was based on the book (which was fictional), we thought that the stones were really passed out in NYC and some field in Pennsylvania.  Everyone in my family were staring at each other asking 'is this guy for real?'.  From other negative reviews, it sounds like the book doesn't do a good job either of distinguishing whether it is fictional or not.  I guess maybe we should have read the book first, but the person who gave us the DVD simply said to watch the DVD.Second, he makes the claim in the movie that when he wrote the book that he didn't even have to work because the book wrote itself, and therefore he can't take credit for the book.  Does this sound like a false prophet to you?  This is when we turned the movie off in disgust.  No one in my family was fooled and we were shocked that this movie (and book) received such great reviews.Third, he talks about the falling away of America, but never once mentions the remedy.  Never is Christ and the gospel of salvation talked about.  The collapse of a once great nation is an easy story to sell, and it appears Mr. Cahn has succeeded in selling it once again.  It is extremely troublesome to hear someone talk about the collapse of morals in our country but to never once mention the One and only remedy.  The wrath of God abides upon the heads of all men, and America is no exception, regardless of how pious our forefathers were.  Simply correcting our moral code will not solve Americas' problems.The movie offers very little new information that isn't already common knowledge, so this DVD doesn't even act as a informational documentary.  Typically when I watch a documentary, I expect something new and insightful.  This DVD doesn't even offer that.I highly recommend that new Christians do not watch this as it is a distraction.  You would be much better in getting a good study bible.

reviewText: The film sought to reinforce the premises presented in the book, The Harbinger.  The film would have been much better had Rabbi Cahn been the sole narrator.  The main narrator's voice was not so pleasing.  Rabbi Cahn's Isaiah 9:10 video is outstanding as he is the sole narrator with an exceptional oratory presentation.

reviewText: I really can't say if the message was good or not since the MUSIC was playing twice as loud as the narrator.  I tried playing this DVD on a BluRay player and on a laptop and neither device could filter the music out enough to figure out what the guy was saying.  The DVD didn't have subtitles either or I would have just muted the volume and read it.  Terrible.  I really wanted to hear what he had to say.
summary: Great music, couldn't hear the man talking worth a hoot.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had read The Harbinger about a year ago and remembered I liked it. I saw this offered and decided to buy it, glad I did. It's kind of like a synopsis and explanation of the book. It left me shaken and thinking, Oh my gosh, we really are in trouble! For those who believe in the Bible and prophecy, this is for you!
summary: If you read The Harbinger, you need to see this video
Title: N/A

reviewText: Jonathan Cahn has gone the extra step here and produced a study guide that really gives one pause for contemplating each issue from your own perspective and caused me to ask myself some hard questions.  Funny how one can read a book and think that you understand all the concepts, but then when you go back and attempt to apply all those things you think you learned, you may find it a little bit more difficult than first imagined.
summary: Great Companion to the "Harbinger" Film or Book
